description:
This lobby bar rivals some restaurants I've been to! The Lounge at Ritz Carlton offers great food and drinks, both served with a high attention to detail. I've had the salmon here a couple times, definitely would recommend. Although their menu is relatively small since its a lobby bar, it offers a good variety of choices.

We recently went here with a party of 8 and staff was very attentive. Service was consistent throughout our lunch. Drinks remained filled and they made sure we enough bar bites while waiting for our orders. The staff is also very professional!

TIP: Seating by the fireplace (opposite the bar) has great lighting from the floor to ceiling windows!
author: Bryan R.

description: Everyone that works here is friendly, hospitable, and super attentive. Almost all of them know me by name which is awesome. Kitchen can be flexible, they will make you anything possible  if you ask nicely. Great Sunday hang out-Love it!
author: Fuey D.

description:
We had a lovely evening - pre dinner and post dinner - sitting in the lounge at the Ritz listening to Sony Holland sing. We had never heard her before, so that was a real treat. 

The staff were helpful and attentive, whether we ordered drinks or just coffee. And I appreciated that they were not  over-solicitous, just friendly. 

We will definitely be back, particularly if Sony is singing. (My only suggestion to her would be to stand while singing. Her very impressive voice gets lost a bit when she sits throughout. ).
author: Karne N.

description:
I usually dont review lobby bars since they all seem to do the same thing ,however, this one was a bit different. When staying at this particular Ritz, grabbing a bite to eat is not a very easy option, because of its location on Nob Hill it would mean treking down some seriously steep hills to get to the closest cafe hence my many trips to this lounge while staying here. But  I must say after my first time eating here I was blown away. The food coming out of the kitchen is made fresh and to perfection, every detail is covered even down to the house made ketchup.

The great service you would expect at a Ritz property continues into this lounge. The staff here were on their game and made this experience a great one. Simple things go a far way, like my first server remembering me from the day before and although not serving me the second day made an effort to come over and say welcome back.

Seating is very much like a lounge with a mix variety of furniture including lounge type couches to table and chairs, as well as bar seating. The feel here is of relaxing and just taking your time and is shown with the service, you are not rushed here one bit which can be a little troublesome if you are in a rush. 

Overall this place was a great option if you are staying in the nob hill area and just want a relaxing space with good food and great service.
author: Avi P.

description:
For such a swanky bar in such a high-end hotel in San Francisco, I assumed service would be on par (at least with their prices - hello, $25 cheeseburger and fries!). Ultimately, I wasn't blown away by my experience at 'The Lounge.

Unfortunately, there were....
- Inattentive bartenders (I literally raised my hand for over a minute to get the attention of the bartender, just to get a refill of water - this is very basic stuff, guys)
- Over-priced drinks for the quality that you get
- Undercooked burgers served (medium rare doesn't mean raw in the center, guys)

Pretty standard for a lounge in the city, but NOT by the Ritz Carlton's standards.
author: Claire S.

description: Impossible to get ahold of a live human being to make a reservation. Real waste of my time. Nothing luxury or 5 star about the service at this place. 100's of better places in SF to go!
author: Maya G.

description:
Afternoon tea in the lounge had so much potential but was such a huge disappointment. 

Pricing is a little steep compared to other SF tea rooms because it's in the Ritz Carlton hotel. This would have been a non-issue had I received excellent service and amazing food. However, the food was not only completely forgettable, it was also incredibly lackluster. Everything was either OK or not even worth finishing. I've been to over 10 tea rooms in the area and I usually never have a problem finishing my food. Tables are tiny and there was barely any space for our tea pots and plates (see photo).

Also note that the photos they have on the RC website for afternoon tea are NOT ACCURATE. Look at Yelp photos instead if you're curious to see what the spread looks like. 

Another issue was that it was evident their servers knew NOTHING about tea. I had 2 different servers and both of them were in desperate need of training. I asked the first server for a tea recommendation but he couldn't even answer my question. He also couldn't even describe the teas I asked about...In every other tea room I've been to, they present the spread and describe the food/dessert included in your three tiered stand. Our server didn't know half the stuff in our stand and used the vaguest words to BS his way through it. To add fuel to the fire, we barely got refills for our tea and had to flag down our servers to pay the bill.

For $65, I wouldn't hesitate to say the Lounge's afternoon tea is NOT WORTH IT. Please go to the other wonderful tea rooms nearby (ie. Charles Chocolates, The English Rose)
author: June Y.

description: The service was excellent and staff extremely attentive. The menu was limited but had a nice selection for lunch. The crabcake BLT was tasty, a wonderful Cesar salad and the burgers looked great! Nice widow table for 2 with a view of the city. Not as pricey as you would think for the Ritz and a great spot for a romantic, quite bite...The valet parking was also convenient, they mentioned $ 20.00 fee but I was never charged, just tipped the valet accordingly.
author: Mark P.

description:
Came here on a Sunday for drinks only.

Pros:
Great service at the bar
Ordered a regular beer but it was great.
Great views of the courtyard of the Ritz and downtown SF. 
Fancy, fancy and posh for sure.

Cons:
Very expensive, to be expected I guess at the Ritz!
author: Simon C.

description: We had the very best and indulgent tea for a dear friend.  It was worth every penny and you should not hesitate to enjoy the lounge.
author: Mary F.

description:
Nice, "can talk and hear the other person atmosphere" Great for a hotel lounge. Serve a drink that can mellow you even though lots of ice. 
Elsa's service was outstanding. Served with a smile 
Recommend for cocktails in the evening.
author: Judy M.

description: A group of us finally tried the high tea at the Ritz Lounge yesterday, as expected the tea room was elegant and service from the staffs were 5 star.  There was live harp performance, the lady Laura was playing princess song by request for my 4 year old, what a nice touch.  We tried various tea and they were good. I had very high expectation but was a bit disappointed.  We ordered the Traditional tea option, it came with 4 piece of hors d'oeuvre instead of sandwiches, and the rest were yummy sweets (chocolate, scone, lemon cake, tart...).  Overall it was very nice but it would have been more satisfying to see a better balance between food and dessert.  I would still recommend this for a special occasion since it's so elegantly done.
author: AJ W.

description:
This review is for their afternoon tea.  First of all, I know they don't offer afternoon tea service every weekend, and I'm not sure if it's offered year-round or only in the fall/winter.  You can check their website for dates of availability as well as fill out a form to make a reservation.  I would probably call rather than book online, though, as you can get a more immediate response that way.  

We parked at the Sutter-Stockton garage which is only a (steep) block or two away.  You will see the Lobby Lounge right as you enter the hotel.  There is no hostess podium, but when you enter someone will come over and check you in.  Their tea is expensive, but when you are there you will see why.  The ambiance is very nice, and customer service good.  They've got some really friendly ladies working there :)  And there's a harpist playing music - how cool is that?!  As for the food, can I say BEST SCONES EVER?!  So delicious!  Teas were good (vanilla bean tea, yum!), desserts ok, sandwiches though - eh.  Too fancy shmancy for my taste buds!

At about $65 (for their Traditional Tea), this is a bit too expensive to do on a regular basis, but worth the once in awhile splurge!
author: Carnita M.

description:
Great place to grab a appetizer and some drinks. The staff is extremely helpful and always does their best to help you with all of your needs. 

Everyone is great at this place
author: Michel G.

description:
A great space.
It's polished.
It's classic.
It's quiet.

If I'm going to be honest,
& I'm going to be,
then I have to say that I prefer this space to the restaurant, Parallel 37.

If you sit at a table, you're sitting in these classic refined upholstered chairs.  They're not passé, they're not modern.  Think classic chic.  Like Ralph Lauren.

I could see Ernest Hemingway having a drink in this room in one of these chairs.  Totally.

Service is not exactly swift.
Ok, it was slow.
But that may be just because we went through a server instead of going to the bar ourselves.  You reap what you sow.  

It definitely warrants a place on the best SF hotel drink list.  
The Big Four.  Dirty Habit.  The Tonga Room.  Anzu.  The Ritz Lounge.  
All gems.

I'm still on the fence about MKT @ The Four Seasons.  It was pretty meh.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
Service during afternoon tea was Very, very, VERY disappointing. 

Keep this in mind:
They only offer tea twice a month. Reservations must be made in advance. It's pricey. Most importantly, it's the Ritz. So there was such a  high anticipation for experiencing a high caliber tea service that left us mesmerized. 

With that said, our server only checked up on us towards the end of our tea. She never bothered to even refill our tea. We had to constantly seek out other staff to refill our tea and water. 

I've been to tea service at the Palace and Rotunda. The Palace beats the Ritz hands down. We left so very disappointed, underwhelmed and annoyed at the lack of Ritz white glove service. 

Do yourself a favor and just go straight to the Palace or Rotunda.

The only reason a two star is even deserved, aside from the fact that Yelp doesn't do 0 stars, was Travis who was kind enough to give our daughter a very awesome gift. The food was good. And Linda stepped up when our server disappeared forever on us.
author: Karen B.

description: Sat at the bar, Jennifer was great!  After a long day, I ended up with a Moscow Mule (made with Australian Bundaberg - yes!) and a bowl of warm olives.  The Lounge servers are very friendly, the décor is perfect, and views are great!
author: Patricia N.

description: Review for afternoon tea: I've been to tons of afternoon tea, all over the world at many different price points. Service is ok and food is ok. Although we were promptly seated, it took a while for anyone to come to take our orders and later, refill our tea. I don't think the food was very memorable either - I remember not being particularly impressed. We sat next to the harp player - who played beautifully, but the volume was a bit distracting. The seats are not very comfortable for your back - ask for extra pillows. Now the room is beautiful and I do love the classic environment. I just don't think it's worth the price for what it offers. Again, what I am referring to when I say "worth the price" is that what you pay for is the brand and image, over quality of food and customer service.
author: Frannie C.

description: Great lounge! Amazing cocktail menu! Come here to be taken care of! We had Neziel and she was amazing! The ambiance is beautiful, the drinks are special and the service is perfect! After all.. you are at the Ritz and it feels like it!!
author: Tricia M.

description: I had a high tea here Last Saturday. I was so lucky to have a window seat where can see the city buildings. Everything was perfect, the tea, cakes, live music, environment, but the price. I think it is a little high, but I still recommend. A really fancy place to talk with friends.
author: Ikkzz Z.

description:
It is a great place
Perfect location
The funny thing is that I have rented a car for $30 a day at the airport and I have it here at valet parking and they are charging me for $72.95 a night
I think this could be the most expensive valet parking I have ever paid
author: Jack P.

description: Excellent service and awesome bartenders. You can snack or eat at both spots downstairs. A whiskey sour and pretzel or a dinner or lunch. Both places are nice and spacious and everyone gives excellent customer service... Love I can walk here!
author: Cecilia D.

description: I can't wait until their Afternoon Tea resumes! I celebrated my bday here with a group of gfs. We had the "Ritz-Carlton" experience - everything you would expect from this brand: excellent customer service, elegant setting and complete satisfaction. A harpist was playing beautiful melodies in the lobby lounge adding to the ambiance. Our menu consisted of choosing 3 types of teas and two 3-tired platters of the most delectable confections, pastries, scones, tea sandwiches, etc. It was beautifully presented and everything was up to par on taste. The waiter was so so so sweet and awesome. He always came around and made sure every tea cup was filled.  He also brought out a special dessert for me as a bday surprise. All the gals had a great time. It was surly an unforgettable bday celebration.
author: Liv A.

description: Great choice if you are looking for nice ambiance and customer service. Food is okay but not impressive.
author: Siruo Z.

description: Classic chic! It's elegant! The service isn't exactly swift but very welcoming, friendly and nice! I was snacking for lunch and got to kill time so have been using there wifi and chilling here for hours in the afternoon... The soup of the day was fresh artichoke soup...didn't think it's my cup of tea yet it turned out to be great! I actually liked it a lot... So fresh and the truffle oil blended in really well! A soup was actually all I needed but I decided to try their dim sum in the menu (appetizer). It's a sampler of 5 dim sum dumplings (shrimp dumpling "har gao", Shanghai soup dumpling "xiao long bao" , pork and chives dumpling, spinach dumpling, shumai) served in a traditional bamboo steamer... The dim sum is so so (average), nothing exciting, just like the ones you get from a decent Chinese restaurant. I had a green tea with my meal... Not so impressed when they brought me my check without me asking for it...I added a coffee then ;p server was nice and recommended me their best coffee and offered that on the house ;) all in all I enjoyed my time here! Recommend it...and plan to come for their tea and drinks in future!!
author: Una L.

description:
Beautiful and elegant lounge in an equally gorgeous hotel.

I live just across the street, and often bring my friends here for champagne and dinner.  On more than a few occasions, I've run into my out-of-town business colleagues here. The staff is excellent.  

The food and cocktails are rich. I recommend the spaghetti, a bottle of the Ritz, and the Hemingway.

I often write here.  Whenever the deal / pitch-deck deadline is near, and I'm suffering from writer's block - I'll come here for the live music, and I'll bring my moleskine with me, and, soon the ideas come out, and the product concept is ready.  I often bring my colleagues here to talk through the creative stuff.

This place is the closest thing to my own private Hotel Chelsea.  

Life occasionally resembles art within the corridors of the Ritz Carton in San Francisco, and I'm not sure if their other properties can ever lay claim to that feeling, that sensation, and that joy of coming home.
author: Kanishk P.

description:
Sexy friends and I enjoyed drinks here one evening.

Smooth service, as expected for the Ritz-Carlton. At the bar, friendly bartender Napoleon took the time to brainstorm with me, then made us hefty "shots" of banana mudslides, a pleasant, fruity concoction perfect for alcoholic monkeys.

The atmosphere in the lobby lounge is clearly old money (read: stuffy) but the seating was surprisingly comfortable. Their lounge has a view of the surrounding neighborhood, too. It wasn't crowded, but your luck may vary. Of course, go dressed up - we were all decked out.

Drinks cost a pretty penny, but, hey, it's the Ritz.
author: Dave L.

description: Service is always terrific. Gorgeous space and pleasant atmosphere. Great place to meet over coffee or tea.
author: Michelle C.

description:
A short while ago I was in the city for a women in education conference close to the Ritz. Me and a few other speakers stopped by here for a few drinks and to chat about the days events. Now, I have been to the Ritz before so I knew what to expect regarding price, etc. I think you have to walk in knowing your going to pay more than the average place at the Ritz. 

Great service, great atmosphere. Nice place to hold an informal meeting of the minds. Would go back again, and suggest you give the place a visit. But be prepared to spend a little more than average for your drinks and food.
author: Coach M.

description:
Nice place to sit for a cocktail before a night out in the city...the staff is very attentive and the complementary snacks won me over.  although we were not guests of the hotel, we were still able to valet our car....FREE!  Nice touch in the city where parking fees can cause a serious dent in anyone's wallet. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8wGfkHlQyS-tfZYwdQNuMQ?select=bBfdMR5IPyOi5wKXjTXXpw
author: Hayley H.

description:
My local bar!  Good drinks and really good potato chips.  It's embarrassing but I think I get a free drink every time I go, not actually, but because of how many potato chips I eat.  Beautiful space, good for an intimate drink or a small group.  They have a limited menu and everything on it is what you'd expect from a Ritz Carlton bar.  Sometimes there's live music and sometimes there's tourists who use it as a daycare center.  Either one of those facts may affect your enjoyment, so be forewarned.

A friend rented out the bar (or part of it) for an event once and that was well done; when we ate all the little bites they prepared for us, they scrambled to make more.  It's a stark comparison with the restaurant, Parallel 37, which is... adequate.  I've had dinner there, I attended a catered event there, and I had breakfast there.  Adequate food and adequate decor and really inadequate service considering it's a Ritz Carlton.  The Lobby Lounge is where it's at!
author: Kevin S.

description: We went to ritz Carlton for desert and it was absolutely amazing. Right from the hostess to the service and food everything was perfect. We ordered the warm apricot cake with pistachio ice cream - It was super moist and perfectly balanced.
author: Zeesha C.

description: Camber is a brilliant mixologist. Ask her to make you a Manhattan. She is super smart and creates her own cherries and bitters   She is super smart.
author: Rosalie K.

description:
The kid and I rolled in here Friday evening...her for an apple juice and me for a shot of tequila. I'm usually a cheapskate, but every once in a while I like to take her there for the experience and so that she can get some practice "behaving" in nice places.

What I love about the Lobby Lounge is that they don't treat us any differently from the dressed-up tourists and high-spending businessmen. We get the same warm welcome, the same upscale snacks and the same friendly service. Even if I'm in jeans and she's in her school uniform (which, in combination, is a dead give-away that we're not going to be spending a lot of $$), nary an eyebrow is raised.

$19 + tip later, we sauntered out of the hotel feeling quite fancy. Worth every dime!
author: Valeria R.

description: Despite my high expectations of this being the top hotel of the world I have seen better food at a food truck! Fishy shrimp and greasy fries left me sick as a mcdonald  happy meal! I looked forward to my stay here and every moment is another disappointing surprise!! Club level is closed no birthday upgrade and no more Sunday buffet breakfast. Customer service is great! As long as you don't eat and complain about old fish, they disappear .wont be back I can pay less t another hotel this isn't a 5 star hotel food wise! The stars are for the arrival service to the hotel
author: christina S.

description: Apparently closes at 11:30 not 12 am. We were so hungry and really disappointed that they wouldn't even serve us a snack or drink. However the manager made sure we were taken care of and sent the food up to our room! Great service thanks so much! Amazing food so good! Recommend the turkey Ruben yummy!
author: Keysha V.

description:
Our Regional Director took us (my boss and I) and another manager to have Afternoon Tea here for our holiday party. We sat in the Ritz Carlton bar/tea room and we noshed on tea sandwiches for instance, prawn mousse amuse bouche, canapes, and creamed lobster in a mini brioche along with a tower of french pastries and mini desserts while sipping on teas. Sandra and I had the organic pear tea which was lightly sweet and divine. 

I'd come back here and take my mom with me for an afternoon of shopping and merienda.
author: Mika D.

description:
Review numero 30.

Seriously, I had no clue you have a dress code. My ripped jeans awarded me with sideways stares and snooty glances.

I love your drinks but the attitude is something I can do without.
author: Jeri T.

description: The worst service ever - and not just once but consistently throughout our four day stay. Why did I keep going back you ask? I thought surely it won't be as bad this time - but yes it was as bad or worse. Pathetic. Irritating - I'm leaving one star only because there is not an option to leave less.
author: Kelli B.

description: Saturday Afternoon Tea at the Ritz was my mom and my favorite tradition and I am heartbroken that they took it away. I'm also kind of sad that they changed the decor of the Lobby Lounge and took away the elegant paintings in order to create a more modern feel. Bring the Tea back! Don't make me go to the Palace or Fairmont, when our hearts belong to the Ritz.
author: Dominique S.

description:
First off, let me say we WILL be back.
How much fun meeting friends for afternoon tea during the holiday season.
I made reservations in August, and will do the same next year!
Food was delish, seconds offered immediatly, quality outstanding.
We upgraded to the tea that included champagne, and would recommed it to anyone who is not driving. A lovely, gracious addition to the afternoon.
We lingered for more than 2 hours, and our server was as gracious at the end as she was at the begining.
author: Deborah S.

description: Limited menu but everything we ordered was delicious!  Great ambiance with live music.  Perfect place for last minute meal!
author: P T.

description:
I expected more than what this experience brought.  I took a friend to the Ritz for afternoon tea as a belated Christmas gift.  The beautiful china was set on a rather small table which was very low.  The chairs comfortable but again low and too heavy to move up to the table.  The sugar bowl did not have any tongs which made me not want to use the sugar.  We ordered the Traditional Tea which was more like Asian Traditional and certainly not British. One savory was a cucumber roll, one with soft white bread filled with some crab, another with a shrimp which I could not eat because of allergy. Another savory was a sesame seed cracker with tofu on top.  I would have liked some fresh fruit served with this tea for $65.00 per person.  Many of the sweets were Asian such as big fortune cookies with a red sugar glitter...glitter on a fortune cookie?  I liked the scone but it was very small and quite crisp. The tea was delicious and we were given a second pot when the first pot became too cold. 
The service was very friendly.  The harpist was wonderful.  Would I go back?  No.
author: Lesley K.

description:
This was my first time having high tea, so I don't have anything to compare it to.  However I will warn gentlemen readers that have not experienced high tea before; tea does not constitute a meal.  You will get an assortment of finger sandwiches and sweet pastries along with your tea.  But relying on this and tea alone, will not take the place of lunch.

A waitress will swing by with 3 different teas you can try.  I sampled the Vanilla bean Green Tea, and the Shanghai rose tea.  To be honest I cant imagine drinking a large quantity of tea without it accompanying some delicious greasy Chinese food.  

The Ritz Carlton's Lobby Lounge is decorated nicely.  At this time of year they will likely have the fireplace going.  Unfortunately if you sit towards the entrance you will feel a draft every time someone opens the front hotel doors (often).

They have a harpist playing a variety of tunes, including a Lord of the Rings "shire" motif.  The my inner geek rejoiced when I heard it.

Bathroom stalls have floor to ceiling marble walls.... classy.
author: Eric L.

description: The service is the kind one can expect at Ritz Carlton. Food was great. Only downfall is the cramped courters. But that goes with San Francisco.
author: David B.

description:
Fan-flippin-tastic!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I've been to high tea many 'o times.  From the Waldorf Astoria in NYC to the Savoy in London to various little Lisa's Tea Treasures (LTT) all around the Bay.  So I believe that I'm a decent judge of "High Tea".  

For Mom's birthday I gave her the gift of High Tea at the Ritz; something neither of us had done before.  I talked my cousin into taking her mom too and we had a wonderful girls luncheon today: 2 sisters and their adult daughters.

The Ritz is certainly not cutesy.  It's classy.  The cute little sugared violets and beaded doiles you see at LTT are nowhere in sight at the Ritz.  It's Simple.  Sophisticated.  Scrumptious.

First things first - where to park?!!  On this Saturday afternoon we actually found street parking right on Stockton in front of the hotel and there were two other spots right around the corner on Pine.  If we hadn't found street parking we would have parked at the Sutter/Stockton garage.  If you park here - make sure you exit the garage on Bush (it's on the 2nd or 3rd floor of the garage and not at ground level).  From the corner of Bush and Stockton you walk a short (yet steep) block up Stockton to Pine and voila!  If you're walking up from Union Square - simple: take either staircase on the left or right side of the Stockton Tunnel (on the Sutter entrance of the tunnel) and you'll find yourself at Bush and Stockton!  Anything to help my fellow-yelpers avoid paying for that ridiculous valet!!!

But you don't want to know about parking - you want to know about tea!  Since none of us wanted/needed alcohol this afternoon we all opted for the Traditional Tea for $36:
-An entire pot of tea.  You choose 1 of 18 different teas.  Black, green, fruit, flower, decaf, herbal - they have it all!
-Smoked salmon with pickled onion & caviar on dark rye sandwich
-Cucumber, roquefort and walnut on white bread sandwich
-Prociutto & melon on light rye bread sandwich
-Egg & chive sandwich
-Scones with devonshire cream and lemon curd
-Various tea pastries.  Today we got: banana macaron, chocolate macaron, lemon marshmallow, almond shortbread, pistachio tea cake, chocolate cup with cream and blackberry, tiny lemon tart and tiny chocolate tart

What I noticed the most was the quality of the food.  I come from a family of HIGHLY critical home chefs and bakers.  The only item that didn't wow this rather "tough crowd" was the pistachio tea cake.  For my mom and auntie to rave about food like this - it has to be done well.  Food was FAR, FAR above LTT's.  

Oh and the best part?... I mentioned, while making my reservation, that we were celebrating Mom's birthday.  And I was shocked when after we'd finished our tea sandwiches and pastries - the waitress brought out a complimentary order of strawberries and vanilla cream alight with 2 candles!  Perfection!

The fundamental Ritz service was evident.  I don't exactly mean the waiters/waitresses (who were satisfactory) but the overall level of service.  For example - I think we could have stayed 3 hours if we wanted to.  We never felt rushed.  No one hovered and we leisurely sipped the last of our pots of tea long after we'd finished eating.  Top that with the birthday surprise and I was really impressed.

This was worth the money for me.  I'd never take a man near those tea pots - but an afternoon with women will most definitely be repeated in the near future.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Had anyone besides my watermelon martini-swilling cohort been with me on the evening I visited the Ritz Carlton Lobby Lounge for drinks I'd have probably hated it. But his constant commentary on the patrons (moneyed old men), the art (staid and formal 18th and 19th century portraits), even how much the tapestries that hung near his head annoyed him was so entertaining I ended up loving the place. 

When stopping by for an after-work drink, follow these simple steps to ensure a good time amidst the Victorian decor:

Step 1. Bring a sexy drinking companion (a big plus if he/she is ALSO funny) as there is nothing sexy about this lounge or the people who drink here

Step 2. Sit by the window - you'll want to look out of it rather than at your fellow patrons

Step 3. Order wine and forget about everyone else in this stuffy joint. . .
author: Miriam W.

description: Great spot for meetings, but occasionally can get too loud. Plus side is that you'll sometimes get to see a celebrity (I saw the guy who plays Ben on Parks and Rec there the other day). Service is always phenomenal, as are all Ritz Carltons.
author: Jay G.

description:
What the FIG did you do to my pizza!?

They put figs on my figgin' pizza!

Who would have thought that figs on a pizza would taste so good, but they did. 

Before dinner, several coworkers and I stopped in at the Terrace for a drink and an appetizer. I spotted a prosciutto and fig flat bread on the menu and thought it would be fun to mess with our new customer and order some "weird shi*" that us Californians eat.

I am proud to say it was a hit but I did notice he was picking most of the fig off his pizza. And just so that you know, before you start pointing fingers at what we eat here have you taken a step back and checked out what those in Alabama consider gourmet?

Side note, thank Heavens for available air conditioned hotel rooms during a heatwave.
author: V B.

description:
Breathtakingly beautiful architecture and amazing views.  I felt like I was driving up to someone's mansion - but nope, it's the Ritz :)

My cousin and I came here for brunch a few months back when we were scoping out places to have my bridal shower. After their staff graciously gave us a tour of a few of their junior suites, we came downstairs to sample their menu. Their menu changes daily, but I recall everything I had was delicious. They served me what is now my favorite drink, and I can't seem to replicate it or find it anywhere else - the Pearadise (Grey Goose La Poire, club soda, lime juice). So crisp and refreshing! My cousin and I split the bay greens salad with walnuts, dried cranberries, gorgonzola and balsamic vinaigrette dressing. We also split a club sandwich :)

The ambiance is the essence of classic luxury...french-inspired furniture, sprawling windows facing the central garden, soft lighting. It was mostly quiet, other than the occassional "cling"poon against a cup of coffee. I admit, I did feel a bit out of place being the youngest women there, and the only women of color at that. Their clientele is mostly older businessmen and posh middle-aged ladies with wide brimmed hats. Very "Breakfast at Tiffanys."

They earn 5 stars for their service alone. If you haven't experienced serving at the Ritz, it's hard to describe. But they make you feel like you're the most important person in the room. Gotta love 'em for that.
author: Mariela D.

description:
I am Jill's vegetarian friend.  Stale bread sandiwches.  Joy to the world.  lol  

But other than the stale bread, the snacks were yummy.  You know...we don't have Philly cream cheese and stale bread at home...too upscale for us,  lol. 

Jill told me the stale (day old) bread is tradition because it hold the contents better.  Personally I would rather just have soft bread and throw tradition to the wind.  Well, the bread doesn't have to be soft but at least make it fresh.

The tea was superb.  Infuckingcredible tea.  I was like, more more more, lol.  i tried all the different kinds of tea and by the end of the meal I had to go pee-pee like a motheffucker.  I mean...I had to excuse myself to powder my nose in the ladies room.  *ahem*

I love how Jill S. brought her doggie in there, then when she took the dog out the carrying bag the staff got all upset and Jill had to put it away.  Jill is so Paris Hilton sometimes, lol.  

The music there was really nice.  A woman was playing a harp and she was highly skilled and appeared to really be enjoying herself and that made me smile.  

Very sophisticated brunch spot.  I would go back for sure.  It's a nice place.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Afternoon Tea at The Ritz Carlton is only delightful if you are surrounded by good company.  

The service is luke warm and the wait staff were dressed a bit less casual than our group.  I expected a bit more spit, shine and polish but for an experience that all should have, save your $ and make reservations.

Tea and small chef pastry delights were nice but I went to Nordstrom's and really ate afterwards.
author: Shonna H.

description:
To understand the great sadness and sense of loss brought about by my latest experience here over the winter break, it is important to first know the height from which things have fallen. Tea at the Ritz Carlton used to be the standard for afternoon high tea - not a neighborhood hangout, cozy and casual, but a formal sitting room with impeccable service and ambience that almost called to mind the sacred. The moment I noticed my teacup was empty was the same that a server had already arrived to refill it; all of the sandwiches and pastries were excellent and presented perfectly, and the harpist added the ideal touch to the atmosphere.
Over the years the decline has been steady, and unfortunate. Many reasons, probably all of them valid, may contribute to this. But this last experience relegated afternoon tea to one of those large conference rooms, darkened, with portable chairs and tables and fake flickering candles. Long gaps between service have become the norm, although our server was friendly. The food was still very good, but honestly, that almost served to mock the entirety of it. The tea and food for an afternoon tea must be perfect, but an afternoon tea has nothing whatsoever to do with tea and food.
author: David C.

description:
Smart men drink tea.  

Or, rather, they take their ladies to tea.  There's something about a high tea that is distinctly attractive to women.  Perhaps it's the unhurried pace, the quiet atmosphere, and the opportunity for unlimited conversation.  

Eight years ago My Lady and I held our wedding reception here, a tea at the Ritz for our community.  On our anniversary this year, it seemed like a natural way to celebrate.  The service was still first-class.  The room still looked like a ballroom in a European palace.  The harpist was still there, and she was playing melodies that everyone, even the toddlers, could enjoy.  Yes, there were toddlers.  Rich people have children, too.  

There's nothing quite like having sandwiches and petits fours stacked on a three-tier service on your table.  The prosciutto sandwich was amazing!  The salmon sandwich was outstanding!  Various things like the miniature eclair and the pecan tart entertained us with their taste, both in appearance and flavor.  Reminding myself of my manliness, I ordered a tea called "Eros," which turned out to have an interesting combination of flavors.  

The waitstaff made us feel like royalty, and as we enjoyed our two orders of Royal Tea (including the Ritz-Carlton's special champagne), we remembered the elegance of  our first visit and celebrated the longevity of our relationship that led to this visit.  After we thought the meal was over, the staff brought in a surprise tray with "Happy Anniversary" written on it around another dessert!  The afternoon was well worth the $107.31 + tip, which we would gladly pay daily if we were actual royalty, I'm certain.
author: David D.

description:
I was here for a conference, and really enjoyed the services.  The marble bathroom made me want to set up my office there. :)

The location also rocks, complete with typical RC service, and rock star views.
author: Michael J.

description:
On a recent weekend trip to San Francisco, we had early afternoon tea here. We had two 4 year old girls with us and they were so excited to get dressed up and eat tiny food. 

They were very accommodating with our dairy allergy and served my daughter hot chocolate soy milk. She was in heaven. The food was tasty and my tea was perfect. 

There was a harpist performing and she played some childrens music for the girls (Mary Poppins, Little Mermaid, etc.) which was very sweet. 

Overall the staff was very attentive and made it an enjoyable afternoon.
author: Kate B.

description:
Food = good
Service = good
Ambience = busy
Drinks = fantastic

Lives up to its name.  

Setback = prices.  I only went here for a group work after hours event a few years ago...
author: Fannie S.

description:
This is not the newest, trendiest Ritz Carlton I've been too (the decor is very out-dated), but:

1) Service is great. We had a reservation for 2 and the hostess gave us a table for 4 with comfortable couch seating (upon request). Our waitress was 7 months pregnant - but still had a great smile, checked on us every 10 minutes, just very available and attentive. 
2) Tea sets were small, so if you have 2 people, you really have to order 2 sets ($35/each). But the food quality was good. See photo. Lots of yummy goodies: scones, tea sandwiches, cakes and petit fours.
3) Great harpist.
author: Emily L.

description:
Such a wonderful place to enjoy tea and company!  We decided to book a bridal shower here based on its many 5star reviews.  We were not disappointed.  

The service was excellent.  Our server was so attentive and accomodating to our guests.  Everything from the tea to the open faced sandwiches were wonderful.  Oh, and the scones.....can't forget about them.  They were warm and oh so good!  I also really enjoyed their varieties of teas.  They had a great selection to choose from and the person I spoke with over the phone a few days before the party helped me decided which three teas to serve on the day of the party.  And the nicest part was when they brought out a little extra dessert for the bride-to-be with the harpest, sitting nearby, playing the bridal march.  A little corny, maybe, but a perfect touch to end the day.

Everyone there enjoyed themselves so much, we have all decided that afternoon tea at the lobby lounge must be done again.
author: Angela K.

description:
I used to like this place....a lot.
Great, elegant atmosphere, fantastic service and Jazz.
But when we walked in the other night, we noticed right away that there was NO PIANO!
And, they used to have great, old paintings on the walls but they were gone, too.
What's going on?
So, we asked the waiter.  He said that management decided to
redecorate the Lobby Lounge.   And they decided no Jazz anymore.

Big Disappointed Sigh!
The waiter was sorry, too.
But, did you know they have sushi menu?

Check the prices below:

California roll with real crab meat......$27
Spicy tuna, BBQ eel and avocado roll.....$27
Lobster and avocado roll........$45
Tekka maki........$12
Toro-tetsu.......$19
And,
Kappa-maki is..........drum sounds.........

$10.!!!!!!!!!!
Have you ever heard of $10 Kappa-maki?
You know what the FXXX Kappa maki is, right?
It's a Cucumber-roll, for crying out loud.
Ten Bucks for a Cucumber roll!
What kind of cucumber roll is it?
18 inches long?

No, No.
We didn't order it.
There was a group sitting right next to us who ordered sushi.
So, we decided to stay longer to see that how spectacular sushi would be..
When the sushi came to the table,
we could tell by just looking at what they got that
we were so glad we didn't order the sushi.

I don't know what kind of fish they are using but it's very clear 
there is a huge mark-up!

By the way, the rest of the sushi menu included...
Nigiri, of course 2 pieces,
tuna $12,
hamachi $8,
salmon $8,
katsuo $8,
unagi $9,
toro $19,
uni $19,

10 pieces nigiri combo $31,

Sashimi 5 slices of tuna $27,
Sashimi 9 slice combination $35,

WHAT A RIP OFF!

When you walk into the lounge, 
you won't miss the small sushi wagon right in front.

Well, I will still go back there for a nice drink with the great service but I am sorry, I'll miss so much the piano and the live Jazz.
I don't mind paying stopping in for a drink every once in while.

But I DO MIND THE 10 BUCK  CUCUMBER ROLL!

I'll never order the sushi....that's for sure.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I'm much more comfortable slamming down some Nestea out of a red Dixie cup than sipping Blue Sapphire tea from Waterford china. I'm much more comfortable snarfing down a PBJ sandwich than delicately nibbling on a  slice of smoked salmon on rye bread. I'm much more comfortable yelling profanities at the Giants game on TV than sitting with my legs crossed, behaving like a lady.

So imagine my surprise when I not only endured, but actually enjoyed, the few hours spent at the Ritz having afternoon tea for a friend's bridal shower. From the harpist to the lilies adorning each table, from the steady refill of our cups to the bubbly champagne, from the lemon tarts to the raisin scones, each and every detail not only didn't make me feel awkward but actually a little more refined. 

In fact, when I finally coerce some dumb sap who'll overlook my boorish tendencies and my lack of homemaking skills to marry me, I think I'll want to have my bridal shower here as well. I just hope that the Ritz will still be open in about 40 years.
author: .elin f.

description:
The official Ritz motto is this:

 "We are ladies and gentlemen serving ladies and gentlemen."

If only the rest of my life was as civilized as this.  Instead, I am constantly being bombarded by snark, passive-aggressive statements, and sarcasm - from my friends, no less (with friends like these...)   I can accept the abuse, but for this:  it is starting to corrode my own sense of self.  I am starting to reciprocate this bile, and simply, that is just not me.

I identify with the Ritz motto to my core.  It is our duty to be gentle with each other.  I think everyone deserves to be treated like they are special, that everyone deserves the benefit of the doubt, and that your words are your sword.  Let them grace others, not slash them down.  

For a break from the cruel incivility of the world, I find the slightly overpriced cocktails at the Ritz Lobby Lounge to be quite a deal.  You are a fetching, charming lady here, despite all other accounts.

You are respected, treated with care, smiled at, unless you take out your cell phone and start yapping away (not, I.)  No cell phones please.

This place serves up a little fantasy for your life.  If it only reminds you of how ladies and gentlemen should act, it is undoubtedly worth every penny.
author: Kara D.

description:
This is one of the most amazing places I have ever been to. As a Philosopher, I must constantly engage with humans of all types, in order to study them in their natural habitat. The people that come here hold a special place in philosophical discourse. There are notorious San Francisco socialites that run around liked drug-crazed peacocks, screaming and shaking hundred dollar bills at anything that moves. There are widows of Old Business whose husbands owned railroads and steamships and crave the attention of young flesh the way a beast with a strong thirst craves cold blood.   There are Presidents and Prime Ministers from many strange and foreign countries, including some I have never known existed, who seek the consultation of a wise Philosopher, and ask me questions concerning Ethics that sometimes have answers which send thousands of people to their doom.

  These people have no concept of Bankruptcy, and readily pay hundreds of dollars from Swiss Bank accounts for food and drink. It's a terrifying thing to watch, and a dangerous thing to get involved with. Dealing with these people is like dealing with electric eels or high-powered jungle apes; keep the food in front of them and never turn your back.
        I have had the pleasure of meeting some of the most interesting and intriguing people I could hope to study, all while getting some of the best service and hospitality one could hope for. 

Oh damn! I almost forgot! The Ritz has THE BEST sushi that I have ever had in my life! The sushi chef, Hiroshi Takama, is the most brilliant sushi chef I have ever met!
author: Dave G.

description:
I recently scheduled a high tea here with a rather prissy friend that was visiting me from out of town. Having had High Tea at the London Ritz, which is the ultimate tea experience, I was quite sure that I would walk away feeling disappointed and that it wasn't up to par.  Perhaps the Terrace Room isn't as fancy, but is really quite lovely.

We chose the most expensive tea, priced at $41, and the only difference that I could see was that you get a Ritz champagne rather than the Gloria Ferrar.  I am not really sure it was worth the extra $7, but I am not an expert on champagnes.  However, the food and service were magnificent!  I highly reccommend their Blue Sapphire tea!

This is the perfect way to end an afternoon of shopping in Union Square with the girls as it's right up the hill on Stockton.
author: Amy Z.

description: I came here Sun for a gf's bridal shower. I enjoyed the experience as I was in good company. However, for the Ritz, the service was mediocre. For the price I prefer the Rotunda for afternoon tea experience.
author: Mimi T.

description:
We came here for my sister's birthday and they are very accomodating to B-day Teas! Let them know before the b-day person arrives and they'll let you know that the afternoon harpist will play a special Happy B-day song and the lounge will provide complimentary strawberries and cream. 

Now let's get to the tea experience:
I love to tea. I've only tea'd around Los Angeles - Four Seasons (service was too slow),Bel-Air Hotel (ambiance wasn't as exsquisite as I hoped) , Beverly Hills Hotel (we had a server from Jersey that completely killed the elegant afternoon tea mood) and some place in Redondo Beach where you could pick a girly hat to wear through out tea though the hats were very dirty, but we wont go there... so I've done my share of tea outings. The Ritz turned out to be the whole package - we orderd the Champagne Tea Service which came with your choice of champagne beverage and all the other tea fixins. 

The best of the Ritz included the prompt service, elegant decor, and buttery, warm scones - best scones I've had with the creamy lemon curd and cream. I woulda ate more if I could. 

For a girly and lavisht tea experience, this is your place.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Of course it's expensive as hell, where do you think you're going?

I had afternoon tea here with my friend to celebrate our grad school admissions. I have no complaints. Champagne cocktails were superb and the tea was so good! I liked my friend's choice better, the melange de madeline, but the vanilla rooibos was good too. The tea sandwiches were tea sandwiches. Good and elegantly served, but still tea sandwiches, very simple, can make them at home no sweat. The scones weren't anything to scream about, but the clotted cream and lemon curd were out of this world. 

Don't go if you want a deal. If you want to celebrate something and dress up and have lovely attentive service, then do it.
author: Whitney R.

description:
The best afternoon tea in the City.  Brought my mom here for a "snack" after shopping for her and work for me.  Great selection of tea (I got the mango).  And the traditional tea menu selection is more than enough.  I pretty much loved all of it.  And the service was pretty good, as you'd expect.  Decor was great as well.  Definitely a classic tea service, the way they do it in Great Britain.  But the whole time, my mom was saying how the tea at the Westin St Francis was so much better/cheaper.  I'll have to try it.

But at $29 per person, it's not ridiculously expensive, considering the atmosphere (the service and atmosphere are really what you're paying for).  Otherwise, Lovejoy's is just as good (in terms of food and tea selection).
author: spiff e.

description:
I came here again for my friend's bridal shower last year and I was really excited because I had spent my birthday here having tea just the year before. 

The theme was a classy tea party and so all us women were decked out in cute spring dresses complete with dainty jewelry and fabulous handbags. 

We each had the set that included endless cups of tea, a glass of champagne (premier tea, I think it was) and our own tiered tray of nibbles: finger sandwiches with smoked salmon and caviar, cucumber, egg, mini pastries and freshly baked scones with devon cream and lemon curd. Though these were bite sized, we were all too full to even finish everything on our trays. During bites of food, we also played traditional bridal shower games. I may not look like I'm into playing those kinds of cute games, but watch out, I'm extremely competetive. Who doesn't want to win?!

If you want a good place to have a nice, relaxed girly get together with friends as well as have great views of the city, look no further.
author: kristin e.

description:
This is ONLY place for afternoon tea. The tea selection is great but the best aspects are: the attentive service, the open faced sandwiches and other treats. The other Ritz hotels, i.e., London, Half Moon Bay, etc left the crusts on their sandwiches! yuck. 

However, recently they changed the china, and it is no longer the delicate, thin or beautiful design it once was. That is the only strike against them.
author: Sloaths H.

description: Afternoon Tea at the Ritz - there are few pleasures in life more glamorous or better designed to make you forget all your cares.   Start with champaign or a champaign-cocktail.  Move on to the egg, cucumber, proscuitto and salmon sandwiches (no crusts, bien sur).  Next comes the raison scones with clotted cream, lemon curd and strawberry jam, the pastries (fruit tarts and cream puffs) and the desserts (cookies and a chocolate and pistacchio layer cake that is bite size).  Oh yes, and tea.  The ceiling is a mile high, there's sunlight beaming in through the large windows and a harp gently playing in the background.  In a word, heavan.
author: Debbie A.

description:
Tea with the girls on a beautiful Sunday afternoon reminiscing about Tea at the Peninsula in Hong Kong... What could be better?!.... Tea at the Peninsula in Hong Kong! 

Service was great, our waitress was super sweet, doormen sincere and adorable. To live this life all the time! Prices.. its the Ritz... don't go unless you can justify spending $50 on tea service.
author: melissa g.

description:
I don't stay here, I live in the neighborhood- I come in for drinks regularly, Jennifer the bartender is the best! She's always personable and serves with a smile- Great drinks scotch, and a great ambiance! 
Fabulous but pricey-
author: ryan H.

description:
I was waiting for my friends to have dinner at the dining room in ritz and i got to the hotel early, so I figured to have a drink in the lounge while waiting.  

At first when I walked in, it had an elegant, yet classy design to it.  Shortly after I sat down, a nice waitress asked for my order.  I ordered a long island, thinking I wouldn't have to wait long for my friends to show up.  However, it took my friends 1 1/2 hrs to come in...  

But anyways, that's not the point, because it was comfortable to wait in the lounge while sipping my drink.  The nice waitress didn't ignore me just because I ordered only 1 drink, and she brought me some snacks after she took my order.  She came by 2-3 times during the 11/2 hrs to see if I wanted anything, and I felt that was nice because I was not being ignored nor was she being too attentive.  

Overall, it is a nice place to hang out for happy hour or just to chit chat at.  I was expecting the price of a drink to be slightly higher and it was.  But coming for a 5 star hotel, 15 bucks for a drink and snacks would not be so bad.  I would recommend this place for anyone looking to relax or just enjoy a couple of drinks.
author: John L.

description:
This was my first afternoon tea party experience.  After conducting my usual online research, we went with the "traditional tea" package.  Here is what was included: 

$36.00 ("PER PERSON") 

Selection of Tea - We went with Jasmine Green, and I wanted coffee too, so we got a pitcher of coffee.

Smoked Salmon with Pickled Onion & Caviar on Dark Rye - This was OK.

Cucumber, Roquefort and Walnut on White Bread -  OK too, didn't finish it.

Prosciutto with Melon on Light Rye Bread - Alright.

Egg and Chive Sandwich- My fav.!  I wish I ate like 30 more of these.  Really!

Freshly Baked Scone with Devonshire cream, Lemon Curd and Strawberry Preserves - The scone was delicious with the cream & strawberry preserve spread.

English Tea Cakes, Chef's Choice of Tea Pastries - ordinary, nothing fancy.

Bottom line... the service was great, the ambiance was exquisite, the tea OK, but be aware that the pastries are very very very miniature.  We were fairly ready to eat some more afterwards.  The cookies are literally as big as maybe a dollar coin.  The scone is as big as the Video ipod Nano screen.  We had tons of leftover tea to go another  good 8 rounds. Hence, we were served one kettle each.  

Nice Experience, but not nice enough for 40 bucks per person!  Considering my practical nature, I would not come back here again.  But try it out for the "experience."
author: Noly S.

description:
I met up with 2 friends for tea there in March, and all in all, it was a great experience.  You each get your own pot of tea.  The only thing that we found a little amusing is that we kept getting asked if this was a special occasion, starting from the time my friend made the reservation, when we got out of the car by the front door (we valet parked), when we were being seated, and even after we were seated.  Well, no, not in the sense that they were expecting, not a birthday (although mine was coming up soon, but that's not why we got together), bridal shower, baby shower, (I think there was a bridal or baby shower going on that day too) or anything like that, but it WAS a special occasion for us, in the sense that the 3 of us hadn't seen each other for a couple of years!

Located on the northeast corner of Stockton & Pine.
author: Linda T.

description: It's okay...expensive drinks at a high-end expensive hotel.  Nothing special about the place...just the name?  Old decor...like a old mansion with a long driveway when you pull up...lounge area is old looking (not modern) which I guess is how they wanted it to be their style of classy??  Should be as we were a bunch of young professionals and everyone else is over 40 years of age.  A good place to bring a date for a nightcap...quiet and easy to chat up a storm.
author: Patrick C.

description:
While searching on Yelp for a nice afternoon tea place in the city to take my dear mother for Mother's Day, I saw a review for tea time at Neiman Marcus by a reviewer who took her mother there and had a horrid time.  I ended up contacting this honest reviewer and got the advise to take mummy dearest to the Ritz.  My experience?

SHIZ-ZAM!  BEST TIME EVER WITH MY MOM!  The service was ultra friendly and since it was Mother's Day, my mom and I got our picture taken and a nice gift bag at the end of our 5 star afternoon tea session!  This place was perfect!  I recommend anyone who loves to tea to try this place out!
author: Keika L.

description:
A particularly classy friend of mine took my husband and I here for afternoon tea.  She was in the know and thus reserved a table over-looking the garden and chose a day when her favourite harpist would be playing.  The food is scrumptious; if you frequent teas, you'll know that good clotted cream is hard to come by.  I could have eaten more, but that's usually the case every place I go. 
We went on a rainy day and it was splendid. Go with a VIP, like I did. Tea at the Ritz is 'scrumtrulescent'.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
I wish we had the 4-5 stars experience.  We had that expectation, after all, it is the Ritz and we were very happy with our stay and the service thus far...  We got what we think was the best table, in front of the fireplace, in chilly January.  Unfortunately, they didn't start the fire before they opened (we were the first sitting) but instead when we were near 2/3 done and the person couldn't get it to start after 10 minutes - by now his crisp white shirt is filthy...  after 15+ minute later, he returns...another 10+ minutes later, FIRE!  It sure was nice, toasty and the wonderful crackling sound...

Nothing was great, just ok...luckily, they'll always have the ambience and the wonderful harp music. 

For ultimate tea experience, Victoria's Empress or Butchart Garden should be worth your time.
author: Gloria H.

description: Fantastic afternoon tea!  I would say the Ritz is more refined and intimate than the other renowned hotels offering tea in the city.  I really enjoyed the wide selection of teas and beautiful offerings of savories and sweets offered on their gorgeous china.  It was pricey but worth it to catch up with the girls in this pleasant setting.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
The girl in me, loves a spot of tea every now & again.

Come for tea with your girls and you will feel like you belong in the Junior League. While the harpist plays some familiar tunes in the background (Disney tunes for the abundance of children present), toss back some of that bubbly, sip on some steamy hot tea and relax in the company of your best gal pals. 

The scones here are buttery good, even better when you smear some of that lemon curd all over. We ate through all three tiers in delight, and probably came across 1 or 2 non-use selections. 

Put on your Sunday dress and make a ressie for tea at The Ritz.
author: Kat C.

description:
Look, I can't really talk right now.  They might be watching.  I'll just say this:

Yeah, I was there.  I was undercover.  I had a caesar salad and a hamburger.  Also, a diet coke.  Did I want a scotch?  Of *course* I wanted a scotch!  Stupid question.

Yes, the food was excellent.  The service was perfect.  I felt like royalty.

I've already said too much.  Wait, did you hear that?  Look, I gotta split.  Anyone asks?  I was never here.
author: Doublejack X.

description:
When you want to feel high touch, this is a great place.  They have live jazz/piano/singing at night, and it's a nice atmosphere to just sit and sip on a drink or two with a coworker.  

One of my buddies lives very close to this place, so on a night when we don't want to fight the bar scene, we'll go over to the lobby lounge and have a drink.  

Hard to describe I suppose, other than to say it's what you would expect of the Ritz hotel bar.  Not really a beer kind of place - expect to drink good wine or liquor, and you might be a little out of place if you wear jeans.
author: Adam C.

description:
Came here for high tea last year with my sister. Definitely something you should try once to pretend to be a dainty girl with your sister, your momma, or your momma's momma. I had the Olive Jasmine tea and it was very good. The atmosphere is sophisticated and relaxing, and the service is excellent. The bellinis, cucumber sandwiches, scones, and many pastries were all very good. I came here on an empty stomach though so I'd suggest eating a little something salty before as everything is really small and there are lots of sweets. But don't drink anything beforehand because each person gets a rather large pot of tea. 

Oh, and don't bring your little kid here either. I remember there was a little girl with another party when we were there and she was running around everywhere falling all over herself and yelling. That's just not classy.
author: Jane C.

description: Well let's see, since we were probably the only ones in the lounge who weren't charging things to our expense account, we thought the prices were a little high (although we expected that going to the Ritz) the service was nice ... and fast but the atmosphere wasn't hospitable. It was a Friday night and since I'd never been we popped in. As we sat drinking our $9 beer we noticed the room was in much need up keep. The drapes we dusty and the wall paper was peeling off the walls or discolored in certain areas. They do have a good view and central location and it's easy to get a cab but I'll probably skip it next time.
author: All About Town ..

description: very nice bar located straight ahead when you walk in the front of the hotel.  great place for a casual business meeting with a few people.
author: C R.

description:
Beautiful place for a girly get together.  Everything is lovely.  The harp music adds a nice touch.  The service is impeccable, attentive but not overly obsequious.  
The afternoon tea here is the best in the City and Bay Area.  I've tried the Ritz in Half Moon Bay (really awful desserts and service) and the Palace Hotel (super slow service and over-crowded ambience).

The sandwiches are super fresh and yummy, but oh so SMALL! and FEW!  for $35 they should give you more than 4 - 1"x3" sandwich, a mini scone, 4 petite desserts, and a pot of tea.  Basically, you get ONE of each item you see in the picture (that someone else kindly posted), not the entire 3 layer tray that you're seeing.  But, you're paying for everything else and the experince is incomparable.
The best parking is to park at the STOCKTON garage on a SUNDAY.  Then you walk about only 2 blocks to the Ritz!!  The garage is huge so make sure you exit at the right level to save you the uphill walk.
author: Mimay W.

description: Nice calm and quiet place here in the Ritz Carlton.  Big plus is their down to earth staff, unlike the other dining place in the hotel.  Big kudos for their kids menu, keep it simple for the kids, nothing fancy.  Staff is really nice as well and service is good.  And they let me in with my Oakland A's sweater so I was happy.  :)
author: Neil K.

description:
I've had afternoon tea here with friends.  This was very enjoyable.  If you like afternoon tea, definitely something one should try.  It's pricey, and you're paying for the ambiance, but it's lovely.

We did the prix fixe dinner with four friends because my husband is a fan of Ron Seigel.  The combination of fun/great friends and the amazing food made for an unforgettable experience.  Highly recommend doing this dinner as a real treat.  We had 7 pm reservations and weren't seated until after 8 pm, they couldn't hurry the people in front of us.  We received no apology, etc.  We were there until 1 a.m., at least the waitstaff hung in there with us.  :)  Still a great experience.
author: Susan Y.

description: Best afternoon tea ever =) My mom took me to the Ritz-Carlton for my very first tea experience over 10 years ago and it was awesome. Unfortunately, it's set my standards unbelievably high and nowhere else (the Palace, the St. Francis, the Peninsula in HK, the Plaza in NY)has lived up to the Ritz in my opinion. Some have come close, but this place is still my favorite. The tea is brewed perfectly, the food is good, and the service is always excellent. I also like that the lobby is small and therefore more intimate. The harpist is an excellent feature as well.
author: Sunny C.

description: I was at the Ritz Carlton the other night for an event. We arrived early for the event so we had time to have a glass of wine at the bar. The Ritz Carlton exudes glamour and elegance..with are wine (Truchard Zinfindel..delic.) we were brought complimentary cashews, peanuts and things...yummy.  I will definitley be back to the Ritz for more "wine hour" next time I am in the neighborhood...its fun to make believe your a millionairess!!
author: Michele K.

description: The rating comment next to the two stars is "Meh. I've experienced better." I've experienced better AT THE RITZ-CARLTON. As some of the other reviews have expressed, afternoon tea has gone down-hill over the past few years. High tea in the old lovely lobby lounge, with the beautiful portraits of elegant women from the turn of the century, really set the stage. I was disappointed when the china was changed out to a more contemporary style a few years ago, but I could accept that if everything else had not changed over time. While some people mentioned the harpist, we had the pianist playing music that was appropriate for what it has become - a nice place for a cocktail. Even one of our tea sandwiches was wrapped in a TORTILLA - who thought that was a tea sandwich?? The decor is now very contemporary, which really clashes with the elegance of the Ritz-Carlton. My cousin and I have been coming here for tea for over 25 years; it has been our Christmas tradition. Unfortunately, we now need to find another place.
author: Barbara S.

description:
A friend and I had afternoon tea at the Ritz after my begging to indulge in one of my very favorite fruity pastimes.  We both partook in the tea involving a champagne drink, and I was pretty happy with my mango mimosa (mangosa?).  Our finger sammies were good, especially the open-faced salmon, although don't expect to look too hoity toity while trying to rip the large piece of meat into bite sized pieces with your teeth.  Sadly, we only got a scone apiece, but the clotted cream that accompanied it was good.  The mini desserts were good, but we both agreed that we would have rather had more savories and no little desserts.  The view to the back garden was nice and calm, and as with most teas, had a nice time cathing up and gossiping while eating our dainties in a leisurely manner.  Fortunately, there was no bridal party while we were there (loud squealing bridal parties tend to be a risk you take whenever you endulge in high tea), although there were some obnoxious businessmen nearby who were discussing at great length how they couldn't believe they were at tea, blah blah blah, and really sirs, you were not all that manly.  Drink your teas and shut your traps.  Nonetheless, it was an enjoyable and relaxing afternoon.

Overall, I would come back for tea, and given that high tea is usually somewhat of a haughty affair, the Ritz was relatively well priced.
author: Tanya N.

description: Note- This review pertains only to Afternoon Tea. As an avid tea drinker and lover of tea services, I was excited to try the Ritz's version. I had been to the Ritz in Marina del Rey and tea was excellent. I expected the same from its San Francisco sister. It was not. First, we waited 30 minutes for our table and made a reservation a month ago. Second, it took 25 minutes to get our first platter, which was all savories and was not replenished. Part of the joy of tea is unlimitedness, the complete hedonism of refills. Third, it took another 20 minutes after our platter was empty to get the second serving.  Fourth, there was an obnoxious bridal party wearing cowboy hats, screaming, and doing mock walks down the aisle in the middle of the lobby lounge. Fifth, the harpist played the Alphabet song and sang along. It was not a relaxing, decadent experience I had expected.
author: Noelle Q.

description: We loved having dinner here. They are prepared for any celebration. Food is great quality. Service is outstanding. I'll be coming back for other Birthdays/ anniversaries.
author: Ssrr B.

description: Went here to wait for some friends who were guests of the hotel. From the minute we walked in, the service was excellent. We were told to have a seat anywhere we liked and immediately brought out some goodies to snack on. The martini list was not very big, but my drink was great. We ordered a bottle of champagne and told our waitress that we want to have it opened as soon as our friends arrived. She was so on top of it and when they did finally get there, she had the bottle opened before we sat back down. I was very impressed.
author: Lisa A.

description:
I imagine this is how an advertisement for the Lobby Lounge at the Ritz-Carlton would run:

Tea Time in the Lobby Lounge at the Ritz-Carlton
Friday, Saturday, and Sunday afternoons only.

If your husband is golfing away at the Presidio, and you have already done your shopping for the week, then Tea Time at the Lobby Lounge is for you!  Gather up your daughter(s), mother, and a friend or two and enjoy our rather interesting selection of teas paired with a few bite-sized half sandwiches, and a lot of sweets!  If you are diabetic, we would not recommend our Tea Time treats.  Our decor is English-inspired -- that is why some of the paint is peeling off the walls and some of the tables sway to and fro -- it's all part of the antique feel!  Even though sophisticated attire is highly recommended, don't worry about it if you come in tattered jeans -- we will still serve you as long as you carry a designer bag.  If you don't have a designer bag, then put on one of those box hats with a flower on top, and you might just blend in with the Ladies' Hat Club members that meet here weekly.  This place is kid friendly as well -- our harpist is a complete professional in Disney theme song interpretations.  Requests are taken, but may not be recognized.  Also, be prepared for a very leisurely tea experience, as we only have one wait staff for the entire Lobby Lounge.  If this sounds like it may be a pleasant experience for you, please make reservations about 3 weeks in advance.  For some reason, we are very popular with the hat, book, and wive's clubs in San Francisco.  

To tea and biscuits!
author: Liz C.

description: High tea on a sunny Sunday with a view of the FiDi.  If drinking loose leaf teas and eating super small sandwiches are your thing, then it doesn't get better than the Lobby Lounge at the Ritz!  They a have a selection of 3 preset brunch offers some include a champagne beverage of your choice.  Keep in mind that the selections are for one person only.  Those with bigger appetites like myself, ask for the other menu that features food from their dinning room.  Staff is unbelievably helpful and attentive.  Thumbs up from a dude that isn't a tea drinker!
author: Jason A.

description: My mom and I go for afternoon tea all the time.  Best we've found in the city since the Compass Rose closed.  I'd agree the service is a little casual, but it's very accommodating.  The one time my brother agreed to join us they were happy to replace his tea order with a cheeseburger at the last minute.  Pastries are nicer than those at the palace, and if you have room try the fresh strawberries at the end.  Also, sometimes they have a harp player who's pretty good.  Word of advice:  If you go, park in the garage a block down the hill.  It may not be as classy as valet, but $20 is a little steep if you're only there an hour.
author: Kate S.

description: Who knew a cup of coffee could be so glamorous; the service is near impeccable, the prices are proudly steep, the room is opulently decorated, and the coffee, well, the coffee's not much to speak of, but damn, pretending you can afford to stay there is fun.
author: Jeffrey R.

description: I like the sleek atmosphere this place gives. Most lounges in SF are getting to be too loud and aren't designed for the older crowd. More importantly the Scotch selection here is thorough and that's all I need to say. Music varies which is good even if I come in on days when it's only thumping I know the next day will be classic rock or r&b. Ask for Jennifer, she's one of the best bartenders around.
author: Mike D.

description: Went for the Afternoon Tea service at Ritz today and I was not impressed.  The finger sandwich and dessert selection seemed pale in comparison to The Palace Hotel or Lovejoy's.  Service was subpar considering this is the Ritz. We had to flag our waitress down several times, rather than her checking up on us.  And what's up with the $20 valet parking fee for 1 hr???  What a ripeoff.
author: Jeannie L.

description: Go for Tea. They provide the full experience from champagne cocktails, cucumber sandwiches, salmon with creme fraiche and caviar toasts, to, of course, scones with clotted cream and jam.  It is here I was introduced to a little tea called Olive Jasmine and now can hardly stand to drink a tea that hasn't had its leaves wrapped into an olive shape before being scented with the sweet kisses of jasmine petals.  I drank the entire pot, and was so hopped up its goodness that the bill didn't even phase.   A bit of advice:  go for the tea service that doesn't include dessert...not needed, and a bit anti-climactic after the scones.
author: L W.

description: I've never been here but it sure looks great. I don't have a lot of money so places named "Ritz" sort of intimidate me and remind me of that one song that used to be on VH1's Pop Up Videos. Whatever happened to that show? That was truly like the beginning of DVD commentaries. I bet if there was a Pop Up Video for the Ritz Carlton Lobby Lounge it would say something like (POP!) Did you know that 87% of people have never dunked Ritz crackers in their champagne? And (POP!) Fact: The Ritz Carlton Lobby Lounge does not serve Ritz crackers and (POP) The 1982 single "Putting on the Ritz" made musician Paco a lot of money but (POP) unfortunately due to excessive gambling and MC Hammer syndrome would no longer would be able to rent a room at the Ritz Carlton.
author: Shannon M.

description: I took my mom to have Tea this past Saturday.  I've actually never walked inside the Ritz and I'm kind of shocked at how small the lobby is. Anyway, as you step up the 3 steps to the Lobby Lounge you are greeted to the sounds of a harp player, tapestries and beautifully upholstered chairs.  We ordered the Premier Tea, which was sans the strawberries and cream and chocolates.  At first I was worried that the little bite sized sandwiches wouldn't fulfill my empty stomach, but surprisingly when the desserts came out I was stuffed! Everyone was very tasty. The lychee champagne cocktail was yummy as was the China Rose tea I ordered.  My mom and I enjoyed ourselves and I would highly recommend this place to spend a relaxing afternoon nibbling and sipping fine tea and food.
author: Natalie S.

description: Tea at the Ritz Carlton for my birthday this year was the best idea my girlfriends have had in a long time.  I was super impressed with the elegant decor that didn't feel overly pretentious and the staff was too kind.  I called ahead and asked if I could bring my wee chihuahua in his bag if he promised to stay quiet and contained and they consented, thrilling me to no end!  The tea was delicious and I love the Ritz specialty, Blue Sapphire, it is definetly a "must try".  The little tea sandwiches were prepared to perfection and the tiny pastries and scones gave the perfect taste of sweet.  My vegetarian friend was pleased at the "Vegetarian Tea" offerings as well.  We stayed well past the close of tea time at 4:30pm, enjoying the harpist, views of the city and the sunset...a very happy birthday indeed.
author: Jill D.

description: I came here for my bridal shower and the space is really beautiful. I had a great time because of the company, but the portions & service left a little to be desired considering the per person cost. Our tea was not refilled regularly and when the cups were refilled, the tea wasn't very hot. The food was tasty, but I was starving afterwards. I've had tea at other Ritz Carlton properties, and portions have never been an issue. What I did love was that they brought me a special plate of strawberries and cream with congratulations scribed in chocolate. When they brought it to my table, the harpist played "Here comes the Bride" which I thought was a very special touch.
author: Angela N.

description: My boyfriend and I had high tea at the Ritz lobby lounge yesterday and it was wonderful!  The lobby was decorated with a beautiful display of Daffodils that matched my Kirribilla mellow yellow dress amazingly.  I had the melange de madeline tea and the hibiscus champagne cocktail.  Both were super yummy.  Their cucumber and salmon open sandwiches were very tasty!  I could have had a whole plate of those to myself.  Make sure you make reservations a week or two in advance.
author: Amanda T.

description: I had hi tea here over the weekend. What an experience. I have had tea before at other places in SF like the Rotunda and St. Francis, but I think this one topped the rankings, hands down. The service was flawless. We had about 20 women in our baby shower party. Our waitress was on top of every request we had. I started off with a virgin lychee drink, yum. Then we moved onto the sweets and sandwiches. One of my favorite sandwiches was the salmon sandwich. They are so delicate. The cucumbers were shaved so thinly you could see through each piece. Not that I tried that since I have table manners but trust me, it was sliced very thinly. The sweets were really good, too. I am getting hungry thinking of them now. Our tea time was topped off with strawberries and cream. What a delightful place for tea. The setting is perfect for taking your mom or going with girl friends. There was a live harp player who played divinely, too.
author: Vivian L.

description: I had high tea here for the second time last weekend for a going away party.  We had one of the first reservations, so it was nice and quiet except for the lovely music of the harpist.  The staff is always very friendly and is very attentive to any special occasion you might be celebrating.  I agree with Helen T, the parking is expensive, so you might want to carpool or find street parking on the weekends.
author: Shannon E.

description:
I've been to several afternoon tea places but this one is my favorite in the bay area.  afternoon tea is my most favorite way to be girly.  more than manicures/pedicures.  

I went here after my bachelorette party.  it was such a nice way post hangover to relax and pretend that we were respectable ladies.  

and the tea and food is really good too.  the service too.
author: Mary R.

description: My group of foodie girlfriends like to get together for high tea at least once a year, maybe twice. If I wrote this review two years ago, it would have gotten 5 stars.
