At that time they made sure to ask us, "Would you like evian or San Francisco water" as soon as we sat down. It made us chuckle, but it was still a nice gesture. This time, we had to ask the waitress a couple of times before we got our water and this time we didn't have a choice. They also discontinued my favorite choice of tea at the Ritz, Blue Sapphire! Ugh! Of course our other teas were very good. The madeleine had an exotic fruity flavor. Our treats were scrumptious, esepcially the scones with lemon curd! Mmmm...but the one thing that stands out to me was our slow and inattentive service. Granted, it was crowded. Our reservation was for Saturday afternoon. It was very busy, but I still expect the atmosphere of the Ritz rather than a rushed diner. I appreciated the harp music and overall friendliness of the staff as soon as you step foot in the hotel, but this tea time wasn't as elegant as the first time. I will give them credit for willing to let 6 of us share 3 orders. I suppose I'll give it another try next year. 3.5 starts
author: Farah S.

description:
this past saturday, i had the honor to have such a sweet, sweet time with such 7 lovely, *HOT* ladies sipping afternoon tea ... 

it was a great bonding moment for us ladies ... 

a room filled w/18th and 19th victorian portraits with a sorry ass view of pretty much nothing was a sad start ... perhaps, if they had a view of the bay bridge or perhaps, overlooking the bay, or something to the nature of sf's landmark, it possibly could've been more of an elegant, high class experience ... 

anyhow, let's get to the point ... 

4 types of teas: royal ($49), premier ($41), traditional ($36), vegetarian ($36). we all got the premier w/one vegetarian ... 

for premier, you get the option of wine or champagne cocktail, and us ladies chose the cocktail ... wooh lord, it was quite strong ... and believe it or not, it was strong for the other ladies who are naturalles when it comes to drinking ... here's a brief description of each of the ones we ordered ...

*the blooming flower (hibiscus flower & syrup) = i highly suggest this one ... not only is the color very pretty, but it was the best one out of the 4 we all got ...
*bellini (had a peachy flavor) = a bit tangy, no good ... decent tho ...
*mango madness (mangoy ... bellini was better, but again, the flower...)
*lychee fizz (this was probably the worst one of all of them ... i have no clue how to describe this drink, but i wouldn't order it again).

then, we had the choice of  3 teas ... plenty to choose from, but below are the ones we agreed upon..

*golden assam (my favorite!) quite a character, and distinctly a malty flavor ... very deep, and perfect for breakfast tea ... this would be the kind of tea i wouldn't mind sipping on, while scribblin poetry on a warm sunny day, starin at the golden gate ... yes, indeed ... 
*melange de madeline (not bad, but more so of an elegant blend w/ a moment of luxurious calmness.  seriously, try closing your eyes and inhaling the uplifting aroma of lavender that floats within).
*shanghai rose (very rosey for the nose ... again, it was nice, but my favorite was golden). very exotic...best drunk on a hot night after the sun sets, can't get any more detailed than how ritz would describe the rose ... 

then you get smoked slamon w/picked onion and caviar, cucumber and walnut sandwich on white bread, proscuitto ham and melon, egg and chive, english tea cakes, a wide variety of chef's selection of tea pastries, and lastly, a freshly baked scone w/cream, lemon and curd and preserves ... 

now, for the overall experience?
the food not only came out slow, but the service was very shallow ... not rude, but just simply passive aggressive at seldom points ... and yes, last i remember, i was at the ritz carlton ma'am... 

the ambiance was so so, the harp player wasn't all that spectacular either, and i love tranquil music ...  

i *seriously* personally wasn't really thrilled and satisfied with the service ... coming with the expectations of what the ritz has to offer, i was very VERY disappointed ...  i say this because i love the ritz, and my family has had many engagements at the ritz, so to me, the ritz = my 2nd home ... whether it be my grandparents anniversary, or my cousin's engagement, or whatever special event it may be, we held everything at the ritz (in korea, that is), but to me, the sf ritz = some motel 6 ... *shrugs* just because it's the ritz doesn't mean your experience is automatically a 5+ experience ...

each person chipped in roughly $60 including tip, and believe it or not, we were STILL* crying out for more food ... if anything, i highly suggest you eat something beforehand because you ain't gonna be full off this $60 treat ... you would THINK you would be SOMEWHAT content, and shit, it's not only me being the hungry pig ... 

so yea, my yelp rating?
this would've been a fat 1 star, but i had such a fantastic time with such fine 7 women that i can't help but to give it an extra star.. 

thank you ladies ...
author: Jennifer S.

description: i had afternoon tea at this ritz a couple yrs ago and it was lovely.  i prefer it to the ritz in dana point, b/c they give you the entire pot of tea here so you can refill as much as you want, as opposed to the one in dana point, in which the server comes around at her leisure.  the lounge is lovely here, but the parking is really expensive.
author: Helen T.

description: About what you'd expect. A nice place to sit and enjoy an 8 dollar beer, or a 15 dollar martini, if that's what you're looking for. The martinis and specialty cocktails were great (I had a mango mate-tini which was delicious and an irish coffee which was nice and strong, with a generous dollop of thick whipped cream, but not served quite as hot as it should have been), the atmosphere is casually elegant. The harpist was good- a crowd of little girls had gathered around her, mesmerized, as she rocked out on some disney tunes. I had to deduct a star because the service was definitely lacking, we had to practically grab our waitress by both shoulders and shake her to get her attention, and she forgot our drink order, making us wait around 20 minutes for a pretty simple drink order, although they were not very crowded at all. The Lobby Lounge gets 4 stars though mostly because of the awesome fruit and cheese plate that they whipped up for us- huge slabs of delicious stilton, brie, and chevre, with elegantly sliced pears, figs, a perfect bunch of grapes fit for a Caesar, crackers, and other assorted odds and ends. Definitely a five star fruit and cheese plate, if I ever had one. The food I saw other patrons noshing on looked good too, and the sushi that they were starting to serve as we left looked amazing. I will definitely be back at some point to hit up the sushi cart.
author: Brian H.

description: i spent half a fortune on far too many cosmopolitans, but the bartender was so charming and friendly, the decor so lovely, the ambience so very posh, that i didn't even mind my very empty pockets. or how very very worse for wear i was when i left.
author: Jessi B.

description: My roommate and I were super excited about coming here for high tea, but we were both disappointed. The decor was nice, but the furniture looked old (not in a good antique way). The tea was too weak and the waitress mixed our teas when she refilled our cups.  The pots were big and didn't have cozies so the teas got cold fast.  The little pastries were delicious though. I'd rather go to Lisa's tea treasures down in south bay.
author: Carrie F.
